data.title: "Nos despedimos felices": The Sweet Heat of BEL's Dreamy Spanglish Breakup Anthem
data.meta_description: The Spanglish "Don't Look Back in Anger," BEL's beautiful breakup anthem "Nos Despedimos" is as tender and uplifting as it is irresistibly energizing: A dreamy indie pop song full of love, empathy, and a sweet, seductive heat, the singer/songwriter's latest enchantment promises to heal our heavy hearts and get us soaring once more!
data.text:
The Spanglish â€œDonâ€™t Look Back in Anger,â€ BELâ€™s beautiful breakup anthem â€œNos Despedimosâ€ is as tender and uplifting as it is irresistibly energizing: A dreamy indie pop song full of love, empathy, and a sweet, seductive heat, the singer/songwriterâ€™s latest enchantment promises to heal our heavy hearts and get us soaring once more!

for fans of Charli Adams, Abby Holliday, girlhouse

follow our Todayâ€™s Song(s) playlist

Stream: â€œNos Despedimosâ€ â€“ BEL

The Spanglish â€œDonâ€™t Look Back in Angerâ€ has arrived just in time for us to sweat it out all summer long.

Itâ€™s time to fly: A dreamy indie pop song full of love, empathy, and a sweet, seductive heat, BELâ€™s â€œNos Despedimosâ€ is as tender and uplifting as it is irresistibly energizing: The Californian singer/songwriter soothes, stirs, and reignites our wary hearts in two and a half minutes of beautiful multicultural wonderment, turning a breakup on its head and inspiring us to soar once more.

Asked me how could you be so blind

I said the ending was divine

Thereâ€™s no such thing as wasted time

I think we grow up when we cry

Ya es tiempo de volar

Es tiempo de volar

Nos despedimos felices

Hope you laugh when you see this

No going back and I mean it

Mean it

Nos despedimos felices

Broke your heart into pieces

But youâ€™re on track and I feel it

Feel it

Independently released as a double-single with the song â€œWindow Shoppingâ€ on March 20th, â€œNos Despedimosâ€ is a soul-stirring, breathtaking enchantment. Returning to the spotlight just months after last Novemberâ€™s critically acclaimed third EP Read the Room, Isabel Whelan reminds us not only of her sheer songwriting and vocal prowess, but also that, after four years spent sharing her music with the world, sheâ€™s still got a few more tricks up her sleeve.

A longtime Atwood Magazine artist to watch, BEL has been captivating audiences from day one. â€œHope and the human spirit run wild and free throughoutâ€¦ shaking us awake not with a jolt of raw energy but with a warm wash of soothing sounds and inspiring lyrics,â€ Atwood Magazine wrote of 2020â€™s debut single â€œSilver Line.â€

In a more recent feature on last yearâ€™s Read the Room EP, Atwood Magazine praised the Clovis, California-based singer/songwriter and producer for crafting a â€œbreathtakingly bold, undeniably cathartic, and irresistibly catchyâ€ listening experience: â€œAchingly intimate and unapologetically candid, BELâ€™s latest EP is the perfect example of empowerment through vulnerability,â€ we wrote at the time. â€œRead the Room turns one soulâ€™s inner brooding into warm, wondrous beauty as she spills her guts seven times over. Tender and turbulent, dynamic and demanding, these songs hold nothing back in reminding us what itâ€™s like to hit our low, and how it feels when we finally do bounce back.â€

Whelan tells Atwood Magazine that she wrote â€œNos Despedimosâ€ for her sister, who was going through a breakup at the time and hit hard by the change.

â€œNos despedimos felices translates in English to we say goodbye happily â€“ like â€˜thank God heâ€™s gone,'â€ she explains. â€œI grew up in a bilingual household â€“ my momâ€™s side is from Argentina â€“ so Iâ€™d been wanting to write a song with Spanish lyrics for awhile. Writing something in Spanglish for my sister felt like the best place to start.â€

â€œGrowing up, our grandparents always placed a big importance on learning Spanish and maintaining a connection to the culture. It was the fastest Iâ€™ve ever written a song and I feel like my grandmother was helping me write it from beyond.â€

Go write it down in a letter

I say the bolder the better

Baby, he did you a favor

But you wonâ€™t see it â€™til later

Ya es tiempo de volar

Es tiempo de volar

â€œYa, es tiempo de volar,â€ BEL sings in a hypnotic, invigorating pre-chorus, the energy building around her in electric anticipation of the oncoming climax. Her words, translating to â€œnow, itâ€™s time to fly,â€ are a message to pick ourselves up, dust ourselves off, and keep moving forward with our heads held high.

We can drown in our sorrows and dwell in heartacheâ€™s depths, or we can say goodbye happily and work at moving on, living each day as best, as fully, and as meaningfully as we can, finding reasons to smile and laugh and flood our souls with light and love.

Atwood Magazine caught up with BEL to tale more about the making of her first Spanglish song, finding hope in lifeâ€™s hard times, and her own personal takeaways from â€œNos Despedimos.â€ â€œI hope listeners take away that breakups can be a beautiful thing for growth,â€ she says. Catch up with BEL in our interview below, and stream â€œNos Despedimosâ€ and its equally dreamy B-side, â€œWindow Shopping,â€ both of which are out now on all platforms!

Hope you laugh when you see this

But youâ€™re on track and I feel it

Stream: â€œNos Despedimosâ€ â€“ BEL

BEL: I had been saying for a while that I wanted to start writing lyrics in Spanish. I was nervous about it at first because Iâ€™ve always felt more confident expressing myself in English. It took me some time to find the confidence to express what I wanted to say in Spanish. I definitely tried it before but this song was the first time it truly felt so seamless and like it all clicked.

BEL: I literally played it for her immediately that night after I got home from the session. She had been crashing at my place during her breakupâ€¦I was so excited to show it to her. We danced and cried to the demo and probably played it 30 times on repeat. I sent it to my mom the same night too. My whole family has listened! My little nieces and nephews were singing it when I went home to visit recently. It was really special.

BEL: Yes! My mom is Argentine and a Spanish professor at Fresno State so my siblings and I grew up speaking both Spanish and English with her. We almost exclusively spoke Spanish with my grandparents on my momâ€™s side. My grandmother passed away a couple years ago and she was always super supportive of my music. I have this feeling that she was helping me write this song for my sister. Everything flowed so quickly, the song felt like it wrote itself, and there were little coincidences that made me think she was helping from the other side. I had just met Matias Mora for the first time at this writing session and found out that theyâ€™re also from the central valley. They also speak Spanish so I knew that this was going to be the perfect moment to write a song with Spanish lyrics because I felt more comfortable bouncing lyric ideas back and forth.

My mom used to sing a lot of Joan Baez when we were growing up. I loved that she had songs in both languages and I felt really inspired by that as a kid.

BEL: Por supuesto ğŸ˜‰

BEL: It translates in English to â€œwe said goodbye happilyâ€ but in the context of this song, I meant it more as a â€œgood riddance,â€ like we were happy that person was out of the picture. I wanted to make something that was comforting for my sisterâ€“that saying goodbye to this guy was the right thing to do. The phrase has such a nice rhythm to it in Spanish, everything flows so nicely after it.

BEL: I do too. This song truly felt like it was written in like 20 minutes. Everything just felt SO good and flowed out so quickly once we had â€œnos despedimos felices.â€ I was screaming with excitement.

BEL: My favorite lines are: â€œnos despedimos felices, hope you laugh when you see this, no going back and I mean itâ€ and â€œbaby, he did you a favor but you wonâ€™t see it â€˜til later.â€

BEL: I hope listeners take away that breakups can be a beautiful thing for growth. Itâ€™s easy to feel like time was wasted with someone when it doesnâ€™t work out, but itâ€™s helpful to take it all as an opportunity to learn about yourself and accept the love from all the people around you who are there to lift you out of it.
